body:
A few notes I found. This is not an issue with Ruby 2.0.0 and RSpec 2.13.0.

If you reverse the string and matcher, the test passes

``` ruby
# Ruby 1.9.3p392
describe "issue_820" do

  let(:my_matcher) { /RegexWithCapture(\d)/ }

  context "string.match matcher"
    it "correctly sets the capture with expect" do
      expect("RegexWithCapture7".match(my_matcher)[1]).to eq "7"
    end
    # issue_820 string.match matcher correctly sets the capture with expect
    #    Failure/Error: expect("RegexWithCapture7".match(my_matcher)[1]).to eq "7"
    #    NoMethodError:
    #      undefined method `[]' for /RegexWithCapture(\d)/:Regexp

    it "correctly sets the capture using should" do
      "RegexWithCapture7".match(my_matcher)[1].should eq "7"
    end
    # issue_820 string.match matcher correctly sets the capture using should
    #    Failure/Error: "RegexWithCapture7".match(my_matcher)[1].should eq "7"
    #    NoMethodError:
    #      undefined method `[]' for /RegexWithCapture(\d)/:Regexp
  end

  context "matcher.match string"
    it "correctly sets the capture using should" do
      expect(my_matcher.match("RegexWithCapture7")[1]).to eq "7"
    end
    # Passed

    it "correctly sets the capture using should" do
      my_matcher.match("RegexWithCapture7")[1].should eq "7"
    end
    # Passed
  end

end
```

So I've narrowed this down to the `super()` chain call in [lib/rspec/core/memoized_helpers.rb#L157](https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/53d3c0b0e34235d9472a7e03ada6d0ec3b8d2bc4/lib/rspec/core/memoized_helpers.rb#L157).

At this time, I'm not sure if issue #821 will fix this.

@cupakromer -- good sleuthing!

I'm puzzled by this, too; in my playing with it, there are basic things I take for granted about variables and object references in ruby that appear to be violated by this...it makes me wonder if it's a bug in ruby itself.

OK, I've isolated this to a very small example:

``` ruby
class Base
  define_method :regex do
    /^[a-z]+(\d)$/
  end
end

class Group < Base
  def self.let(name, &block)
    define_method(name) { super() }
  end

  let(:regex) {/^[a-z]+(\d)$/}
end

puts "abcdef8".match(Group.new.regex)[1]
```

I wrote up a [gist](https://gist.github.com/myronmarston/5123087) with an isolated example and have [asked some folks who know ruby better than I do](https://twitter.com/myronmarston/status/310274867800973312) to take a look at it.

That was the route I was heading. When I saw it worked in 2.0.0 and the code was just some usage of `define_method` it seemed odd. Esp, considering every time I just took a peak at the variable (in pry, with puts, etc) things would magically work. True Heisenbug.

As for a temp fix, it seems we can resolve the issue by not passing the block directly to `define_method` on the parent module. Instead we create a new closure which calls the block:

``` ruby
#  lib/rspec/core/memoized_helpers.rb#L152
MemoizedHelpers.module_for(self).define_method(name) do
  block.call
end
```
Based on the comments on the gist, I'm wondering if Peter is on to something with the need for a binding?

That change will break the support for super and return in let declarations that got added in 2.13. These method constructs can only be used if you pass the block directly to define_method. That's the entire reason there's the ancestor module.

I noticed that forcing a nil block using super(&nil) appears to solve it. Want to take a stab at fixing it with that?

Sent from my iPhone

issue.title: Ensure let block is not passed to super call.
issue.body:
Fix #820. This is directly related to bug
http://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8059.  It seems to affect Ruby 1.9.3
but not Ruby 2.0.0. As per the notes, it is a heisenbug, so simply
looking at it causes the bug to disappear.

Force the call to super to make sure the let block is not passed in.

issue.title: Testing a clone fails, unless the clone is invoked first
issue.body:
When doing a customized deep clone, I ran across a situation where the test will fail unless the variable assigned by `let` is called first (see the spec code below).

The cloning _does_ work, but the normal test case fails.

Code to reproduce:

File: `cloner.rb`

``` ruby
class Cloner
  def clone_array_of_hashes(a)
    a.map{|h| h.clone}
  end
end
```

File: `cloner_spec.rb`

``` ruby
require_relative "./cloner"

describe Cloner do
  let(:cloner) {Cloner.new}
  let(:orig_ah) { [{a: "A"},{b: "B"}] }
  let(:cloned_ah) { cloner.clone_array_of_hashes(orig_ah) }

  it "passes" do
    cloned_ah[0] #this is the only difference between the two tests
    orig_ah[0][:a] = "AA"
    expect(orig_ah[0]).to_not eq(cloned_ah[0])
  end

  it "fails but should pass" do
    orig_ah[0][:a] = "AA"
    expect(orig_ah[0]).to_not eq(cloned_ah[0])
  end
end
```

Notes:
- Invoking `cloned_ah` instaed of `cloned_ah[0]` works to pass the test as well.
- The issue exists whether `clone` or `dup` is used

The issue occurs with RSpec  2.14 and 2.12, and Ruby 1.9.3 and 2.0.0

I had a similar issue a while ago with regexes (https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/issues/820) with the variable needing to be invoked first, but I'm not sure if the similarities extend beyond that.
